milestone_12_concern_37: Doesn't search for things that {{heSheTag}} sees you hide.
milestone_12_concern_39: Doesn't learn gestures like waving or shaking head.
milestone_12_hint_55: Give your child time to get to know a new caregiver. Bring a favorite toy, stuffed animal, or blanket to help comfort your child.
milestone_12_hint_56: In response to unwanted behaviors, say "no" firmly. Do not yell, spank, or give long explanations. A time out for 30 seconds to 1 minute might help redirect your child.
milestone_12_hint_57: Give your child lots of hugs, kisses, and praise for good behavior.
milestone_12_hint_58: Talk to your child about what you're doing. For example, "Mommy is washing your hands with a washcloth"
milestone_12_hint_59: Read with your child every day. Have your child turn the pages. Take turns labeling pictures with your child.
milestone_12_hint_60: Build on what your child says or tries to say or what {{heSheTag}} points to. If {{heSheTag}} points to a truck and says "t" or "truck," say, "Yes, that's a big blue truck"
milestone_12_hint_61: Spend a lot more time encouraging wanted behaviors than punishing unwanted behaviors (4 times as much encouragement for wanted behaviors as redirection for unwanted behaviors).
milestone_12_hint_62: Give your child crayons and paper, and let your child draw freely. Show your child how to draw lines up and down and across the page. Praise your child when {{heSheTag}} tries to copy them.
milestone_12_hint_63: Play with blocks, shape sorters, and other toys that encourage your child to use {{hisHersTag}} hands.
milestone_12_hint_64: Hide small toys and other things and have your child find them.
milestone_12_hint_65: Ask your child to label body parts or things you see while driving in the car.
milestone_12_hint_66: Sing songs with actions, like "The Itsy Bitsy Spider" and "Wheels on the Bus". Help your child do the actions with you.
milestone_12_hint_67: Give your child pots and pans or a small musical instrument like a drum or cymbals. Encourage your child to make noise.
milestone_12_hint_68: Provide lots of safe places for your toddler to explore. (Toddler-proof your home. Lock away products for cleaning, laundry, lawn care, and car care. Use a safety gate and lock doors to the outside and the basement.)
milestone_12_hint_69: Give your child push toys like a wagon or "kiddie push car".
milestone_12_skill_102: Follows simple directions like "pick up the toy"
milestone_12_skill_103: Gets to a sitting position without help.
milestone_12_skill_104: Pulls up to stand, walks holding on to furniture ("cruising").
milestone_12_skill_105: May take a few steps without holding on.
milestone_12_skill_80: Is shy or nervous with strangers.
milestone_12_skill_81: Cries when mom or dad leaves.
milestone_12_skill_84: Hands you a book when {{heSheTag}} wants to hear a story.
milestone_12_skill_85: Repeats sounds or actions to get attention.
milestone_12_skill_86: Puts out arm or leg to help with dressing.
milestone_12_skill_89: Uses simple gestures, like shaking head "no" or waving "bye-bye"
milestone_12_skill_90: Makes sounds with changes in tone (sounds more like speech).
milestone_12_skill_92: Tries to say words you say.
milestone_12_skill_93: Explores things in different ways, like shaking, banging, throwing.
milestone_12_skill_95: Looks at the right picture or thing when it's named.
milestone_12_skill_97: Starts to use things correctly. For example, drinks from a cup, brushes hair.
milestone_12_skill_99: Puts things in a container, takes things out of a container.
milestone_18_concern_44: Doesn't notice or mind when a caregiver leaves or returns.
milestone_18_concern_45: Doesn't know what familiar things are for.
milestone_18_concern_46: Doesn't point to show things to others.
milestone_18_hint_70: Provide a safe, loving environment. It's important to be consistent and predictable.
milestone_18_hint_71: Praise good behaviors more than you punish bad behaviors (use only very brief time outs).
milestone_18_hint_72: Describe {{hisHersTag}} emotions. For example, say, "You are happy when we read this book"
milestone_18_hint_74: Encourage empathy. For example, when {{heSheTag}} sees a child who is sad, encourage {{himHerTag}} to hug or pat the other child.
milestone_18_hint_75: Read books and talk about the pictures using simple words.
milestone_18_hint_77: Use words that describe feelings and emotions.
milestone_18_hint_80: Hide things under blankets and pillows and encourage {{himHerTag}} to find them.
milestone_18_hint_81: Play with blocks, balls, puzzles, books, and toys that teach cause and effect and problem solving.
milestone_18_hint_82: Name pictures in books and body parts.
milestone_18_hint_83: Provide toys that encourage pretend play. For example, dolls, play telephones.
milestone_18_hint_84: Provide safe areas for your child to walk and move around in.
milestone_18_hint_85: Provide toys that {{heSheTag}} can push or pull safely.
milestone_18_hint_86: Provide balls for {{himHerTag}} to kick, roll, and throw.
milestone_18_hint_87: Encourage {{himHerTag}} to drink from {{hisHersTag}} cup and use a spoon, no matter how messy.
milestone_18_hint_88: Blow bubbles and let your child pop them.
milestone_18_skill_108: Likes to hand things to others as play.
milestone_18_skill_112: Plays simple pretend, such as feeding a doll.
milestone_18_skill_113: May cling to caregivers in new situations.
milestone_18_skill_114: Points to show others something interesting.
milestone_18_skill_115: Explores alone but with a parents close by
milestone_18_skill_118: Points to show someone what {{heSheTag}} wants.
milestone_18_skill_119: Knows what ordinary things are for. For example, telephone, brush, spoon.
milestone_18_skill_120: Points to get the attention of others.
milestone_18_skill_121: Shows interest in a doll or stuffed animal by pretending to feed.
milestone_18_skill_124: Can follow 1-step verbal commands without any gestures. For example, sits when you say "sit down"
milestone_24_concern_52: Doesn't know what to do with common things, like a brush, phone, fork, or spoon.
milestone_24_concern_55: Doesn't use 2-word phrases. For example, "drink milk"
milestone_24_hint_100: Once your child walks well, ask {{himHerTag}} to carry small things for you.
milestone_24_hint_101: Kick a ball back and forth with your child. When your child is good at that, encourage {{himHerTag}} to run and kick.
milestone_24_hint_102: Take your child to the park to run and climb on equipment or walk on nature trails. Watch your child closely.
milestone_24_hint_103: Read with your child every day. Learn about two amazing and FREE books from CDC at cdc.gov/AmazingBooks
milestone_24_hint_89: Encourage your child to help with simple chores at home, like sweeping and making dinner. Praise your child for being a good helper.
milestone_24_hint_90: At this age, children still play next to (not with) each other and don't share well. For play dates, give the children lots of toys to play with. Watch the children closely and step in if they fight or argue.
milestone_24_hint_91: Give your child attention and praise when {{heSheTag}} follows instructions. Limit attention for defiant behavior. Spend a lot more time praising good behaviors than punishing bad ones.
milestone_24_hint_92: Teach your child to identify and say body parts, animals, and other common things.
milestone_24_hint_93: Do not correct your child when {{heSheTag}} says words incorrectly. Rather, say it correctly. For example, "That is a ball"
milestone_24_hint_94: Encourage your child to say a word instead of pointing. If your child can’t say the whole word ("milk,") give {{himHerTag}} the first sound ("m") to help. Over time, you can prompt your child to say the whole sentence — "I want milk"
milestone_24_hint_95: Hide your child’s toys around the room and let {{himHerTag}} find them.
milestone_24_hint_96: Help your child do puzzles with shapes, colors, or farm animals. Name each piece when your child puts it in place.
milestone_24_hint_97: Encourage your child to play with blocks. Take turns building towers and knocking them down.
milestone_24_hint_98: Do art projects with your child using crayons, paint, and paper. Describe what your child makes and hang it on the wall or refrigerator.
milestone_24_hint_99: Ask your child to help you open doors and drawers and turn pages in a book or magazine.
milestone_24_skill_135: Copies others, especially adults and older children.
milestone_24_skill_136: Gets excited when with other children.
milestone_24_skill_138: Shows defiant behavior. For example, refuses to do what {{heSheTag}} is asked to do.
milestone_24_skill_139: Plays mainly beside other children, but is beginning to include other children, such as in chase games.
milestone_24_skill_140: Points to things or pictures when they are named.
milestone_24_skill_141: Knows names of familiar people and body parts.
milestone_24_skill_145: Points to things in a book.
milestone_24_skill_146: Finds things even when hidden under two or three covers.
milestone_24_skill_147: Begins to sort shapes and colors.
milestone_24_skill_148: Completes sentences and rhymes in familiar books.
milestone_24_skill_150: Builds towers of 4 or more blocks.
milestone_24_skill_151: Might use one hand more than the other.
milestone_24_skill_152: Follows two-step instructions such as “Pick up your shoes and put them in the closet"
milestone_24_skill_153: Names items in a picture book, such as a cat, bird, or dog.
milestone_24_skill_157: Climbs onto and down from furniture without help.
milestone_24_skill_158: Walks up and down stairs holding on.
milestone_24_skill_160: Makes or copies straight lines and circles.
milestone_2_concern_3: Doesn't watch things as they move.
milestone_2_concern_6: Can't hold head up when pushing up when on tummy.
milestone_2_hint_1: Cuddle, talk, and play with your baby during feeding, dressing, and bathing.
milestone_2_hint_10: Place a baby-safe mirror in your baby's crib so {{heSheTag}} can look at {{himselfHerselfTag}}.
milestone_2_hint_11: Look at pictures with your baby and talk about them.
milestone_2_hint_12: Lay your baby on {{hisHersTag}} tummy when {{heSheTag}} is awake and put toys near {{himHerTag}}.
milestone_2_hint_13: Encourage your baby to lift {{hisHersTag}} head by holding toys at eye level in front of {{himHerTag}}.
milestone_2_hint_14: Hold a toy or rattle above your baby’s head and encourage {{himHerTag}} to reach for it.
milestone_2_hint_15: Hold your baby upright with {{hisHersTag}} feet on the floor. Sing or talk to your baby as {{heSheTag}} is upright.
milestone_2_hint_2: Help your baby learn to calm {{himselfHerselfTag}}. It's okay for {{himHerTag}} to suck on {{hisHersTag}} fingers.
milestone_2_hint_3: Begin to help your baby get into a routine, such as sleeping at night more than in the day, and have regular schedules.
milestone_2_hint_4: Getting in tune with your baby's likes and dislikes can help you feel more comfortable and confident.
milestone_2_hint_5: Act excited and smile when your baby makes sounds.
milestone_2_hint_6: Copy your baby's sounds sometimes, but also use clear language.
milestone_2_hint_7: Pay attention to your baby's different cries so that you learn to know what {{heSheTag}} wants.
milestone_2_hint_8: Talk, read, and sing to your baby.
milestone_2_hint_9: Play peek-a-boo. Help your baby play peek-a-boo, too.
milestone_2_skill_10: Makes smoother movements with arms and legs.
milestone_2_skill_2: Can briefly calm {{himselfHerselfTag}} (may bring hands to mouth and suck on hand).
milestone_2_skill_7: Begins to follow things with eyes and recognize people at a distance.
milestone_2_skill_8: Begins to act bored (cries, fussy) if activity doesn't change.
milestone_2_skill_9: Can hold head up and begins to push up when lying on tummy.
milestone_36_concern_59: Falls down a lot or has trouble with stairs.
milestone_36_concern_60: Drools or has very unclear speech.
milestone_36_concern_61: Can't work simple toys (such as peg boards, simple puzzles, turning handle).
milestone_36_concern_65: Doesn't want to play with other children or with toys.
milestone_36_hint_104: Go to play groups with your child or other places where there are other children, to encourage getting along with others.
milestone_36_hint_105: Work with your child to solve the problem when {{heSheTag}} is upset.
milestone_36_hint_106: Talk about your child's emotions. For example, say "I can tell you feel mad because you threw the puzzle piece". Encourage your child to identify feelings in books.
milestone_36_hint_107: Give your child instructions with 2 or 3 steps. For example, "Go to your room and get your shoes and coat"
milestone_36_hint_108: Read to your child every day. Ask your child to point to things in the pictures and repeat words after you.
milestone_36_hint_109: Set rules and limits for your child, and stick to them. If your child breaks a rule, give {{himHerTag}} a time out for 30 seconds to 1 minute in a chair or in {{hisHersTag}} room. Praise your child for following the rules.
milestone_36_hint_110: Give your child an "activity box" with paper, crayons, and coloring books. Color and draw lines and shapes with your child.
milestone_36_hint_111: Play matching games. Ask your child to find objects in books or around the house that are the same.
milestone_36_hint_112: Play counting games. Count body parts, stairs, and other things you use or see every day.
milestone_36_hint_113: Hold your child’s hand going up and down stairs. When {{heSheTag}} can go up and down easily, encourage {{himHerTag}} to use the railing.
milestone_36_hint_114: Play outside with your child. Go to the park or hiking trail. Allow your child to play freely and without structured activities.
milestone_36_hint_115: Read with your child every day. Learn about two amazing and FREE books from CDC at cdc.gov/AmazingBooks
milestone_36_skill_162: Shows affection for friends without prompting.
milestone_36_skill_164: Shows concern for a crying friend.
milestone_36_skill_165: Understands the idea of "mine" and "his" or "hers"
milestone_36_skill_166: Shows a wide range of emotions.
milestone_36_skill_167: Separates easily from mom and dad.
milestone_36_skill_168: May get upset with major changes in routine.
milestone_36_skill_173: Says first name, age, and sex.
milestone_36_skill_175: Says words like "I," "me," "we," and "you" and some plurals (cars, dogs, cats).
milestone_36_skill_176: Talks well enough for strangers to understand most of the time.
milestone_36_skill_177: Carries on a conversation using 2 to 3 sentences.
milestone_36_skill_178: Can work toys with buttons, levers, and moving parts.
milestone_36_skill_179: Plays make-believe with dolls, animals, and people.
milestone_36_skill_182: Copies a circle with pencil or crayon.
milestone_36_skill_183: Turns book pages one at a time.
milestone_36_skill_184: Builds towers of more than 6 blocks.
milestone_36_skill_185: Screws and unscrews jar lids or turns door handle.
milestone_36_skill_189: Walks up and down stairs, one foot on each step.
milestone_48_concern_71: Shows no interest in interactive games or make-believe.
milestone_48_concern_72: Ignores other children or doesn't respond to people outside the family.
milestone_48_concern_73: Resists dressing, sleeping, and using the toilet.
milestone_48_hint_116: Play make-believe with your child. Let {{himHerTag}} be the leader and copy what {{heSheTag}} is doing.
milestone_48_hint_117: Suggest your child pretend play an upcoming event that might make {{himHerTag}} nervous, like going to preschool or staying overnight at a grandparent's house.
milestone_48_hint_118: Give your child simple choices whenever you can. Let your child choose what to wear, play, or eat for a snack. Limit choices to 2 or 3.
milestone_48_hint_119: Encourage your child to use words, share toys, and take turns playing games of one another's choice.
milestone_48_hint_120: Give your child toys to build imagination, like dress-up clothes, kitchen sets, and blocks.
milestone_48_hint_121: Use good grammar when speaking to your child. Instead of, "Mommy wants you to come here," say," I want you to come here"
milestone_48_hint_122: During play dates, let your child solve {{himHerTag}} own problems with friends, but be nearby to help out if needed.
milestone_48_hint_123: Use words like "first," "second," and "finally" when talking about everyday activities. This will help your child learn about sequence of events.
milestone_48_hint_124: Take time to answer your child’s "why" questions. If you don’t know the answer, say "I don’t know," or help your child find the answer in a book, on the Internet, or from another adult.
milestone_48_hint_125: When you read with your child, ask {{himHerTag}} to tell you what happened in the story as you go.
milestone_48_hint_126: Say colors in books, pictures, and things at home. Count common items, like the number of snack crackers, stairs, or toy trains.
milestone_48_hint_127: Teach your child to play outdoor games like tag, follow the leader, and duck, duck, goose.
milestone_48_hint_128: Play your child’s favorite music and dance with your child. Take turns copying each other’s moves.
milestone_48_skill_192: Is more and more creative with make-believe play.
milestone_48_skill_193: Would rather play with other children than by {{himselfHerselfTag}}.
milestone_48_skill_195: Often can’t tell what’s real and what’s make-believe.
milestone_48_skill_196: Talks about what {{heSheTag}} likes and what {{heSheTag}} is interested in.
milestone_48_skill_197: Knows some basic rules of grammar, such as correctly using "he" and "she"
milestone_48_skill_198: Sings a song or says a poem from memory, such as the "Itsy Bitsy Spider" or "The Wheels on the Bus"
milestone_48_skill_200: Can say first and last name.
milestone_48_skill_201: Names some colors and some numbers.
milestone_48_skill_206: Draws a person with 2 to 4 body parts.
milestone_48_skill_208: Starts to copy some capital letters.
milestone_48_skill_210: Tells you what {{heSheTag}} thinks is going to happen next in a book.
milestone_48_skill_211: Hops and stands on one foot up to 2 seconds.
milestone_48_skill_212: Catches a bounced ball most of the time.
milestone_48_skill_213: Pours, cuts with supervision, and mashes own food.
milestone_4_concern_13: Doesn't push down with legs when feet are placed on a hard surface.
milestone_4_concern_14: Has trouble moving one or both eyes in all directions.
milestone_4_concern_8: Doesn't watch things as they move.
milestone_4_hint_16: Hold and talk to your baby; smile and be cheerful while you do.
milestone_4_hint_17: Set steady routines for sleeping and feeding.
milestone_4_hint_18: Pay close attention to what your baby likes and doesn't like; you will know how best to meet {{hisHersTag}} needs and what you can do to make your baby happy.
milestone_4_hint_20: Act excited and smile when your baby makes sounds.
milestone_4_hint_21: Have quiet play times when you read or sing to your baby.
milestone_4_hint_22: Give age-appropriate toys to play with, such as rattles or colorful pictures.
milestone_4_hint_24: Provide safe opportunities for your baby to reach for toys and explore {{hisHersTag}} surroundings.
milestone_4_hint_25: Put toys near your baby so that {{heSheTag}} can reach for them or kick {{hisHersTag}} feet.
milestone_4_hint_26: Put toys or rattles in your baby’s hand and help {{himHerTag}} to hold them.
milestone_4_hint_27: Hold your baby upright with feet on the floor, and sing or talk to your baby as {{heSheTag}} "stands" with support.
milestone_4_skill_16: Likes to play with people and might cry when playing stops.
milestone_4_skill_17: Copies some movements and facial expressions, like smiling or frowning.
milestone_4_skill_19: Babbles with expression and copies sounds {{heSheTag}} hears.
milestone_4_skill_20: Cries in different ways to show hunger, pain, or being tired.
milestone_4_skill_21: Lets you know if {{heSheTag}} is happy or sad.
milestone_4_skill_23: Reaches for toy with one hand.
milestone_4_skill_24: Uses hands and eyes together, such as seeing a toy and reaching for it.
milestone_4_skill_25: Follows moving things with eyes from side to side.
milestone_4_skill_27: Recognizes familiar people and things at a distance.
milestone_4_skill_29: Pushes down on legs when feet are on a hard surface.
milestone_4_skill_30: May be able to roll over from tummy to back.
milestone_4_skill_31: Can hold a toy and shake it and swing at dangling toys.
milestone_4_skill_33: When lying on stomach, pushes up to elbows.
milestone_60_concern_81: Doesn't show a wide range of emotions.
milestone_60_concern_82: Shows extreme behavior (unusually fearful, aggressive, shy, or sad).
milestone_60_concern_84: Is easily distracted, has trouble focusing on one activity for more than 5 minutes.
milestone_60_concern_85: Doesn't respond to people, or responds only superficially.
milestone_60_concern_86: Can't tell what's real and what's make-believe.
milestone_60_concern_87: Doesn't play a variety of games and activities.
milestone_60_concern_88: Can't give first and last name.
milestone_60_concern_89: Doesn't use plurals or past tense properly.
milestone_60_concern_90: Doesn't talk about daily activities or experiences.
milestone_60_concern_92: Can't brush teeth, wash and dry hands, or get undressed without help.
milestone_60_hint_129: Continue to arrange play dates, trips to the park, or play groups. Give your child more freedom to choose activities to play with friends, and let your child work out problems on {{hisHersTag}} own.
milestone_60_hint_130: This is a good time to talk to your child about safe touch. No one should touch "private parts" except doctors or nurses during an exam or parents when they are trying to keep the child clean.
milestone_60_hint_131: Teach your child {{hisHersTag}} address and phone number.
milestone_60_hint_132: When reading to your child, ask {{himHerTag}} to predict what will happen next in the story.
milestone_60_hint_133: Encourage your child to "read" by looking at the pictures and telling the story.
milestone_60_hint_134: Your child might start to talk back or use profanity (swear words) as a way to feel independent. Do not give a lot of attention to this talk, other than a brief time out. Instead, praise your child when {{heSheTag}} asks for things nicely and calmly takes "no" for an answer.
milestone_60_hint_135: Teach your child time concepts like morning, afternoon, evening, today, tomorrow, and yesterday. Start teaching the days of the week.
milestone_60_hint_136: Explore your child’s interests in your community. For example, if your child loves animals, visit the zoo or petting farm. Go to the library or look on the Internet to learn about these topics.
milestone_60_hint_137: Keep a handy box of crayons, paper, paint, child scissors, and paste. Encourage your child to draw and make art projects with different supplies.
milestone_60_hint_138: Play with toys that encourage your child to put things together.
milestone_60_hint_139: Teach your child how to pump {{hisHersTag}} legs back and forth on a swing.
milestone_60_hint_140: Help your child climb on the monkey bars.
milestone_60_hint_141: Go on walks with your child, do a scavenger hunt in your neighborhood or park, help {{himHerTag}} ride a bike with training wheels (wearing a helmet).
milestone_60_skill_216: More likely to agree with rules.
milestone_60_skill_217: Likes to sing, dance, and act.
milestone_60_skill_219: Can tell what's real and what's make-believe.
milestone_60_skill_220: Shows more independence (for example, may visit a next-door neighbor by {{himselfHerselfTag}} [adult supervision is still needed])
milestone_60_skill_221: Is sometimes demanding and sometimes very cooperative.
milestone_60_skill_223: Tells a simple story using full sentences.
milestone_60_skill_224: Uses future tense. For example, "Grandma will be here"
milestone_60_skill_227: Can draw a person with at least 6 body parts.
milestone_60_skill_228: Can print some letters and numbers.
milestone_60_skill_229: Copies a triangle and other shapes.
milestone_60_skill_230: Knows about things used every day, like money and food.
milestone_60_skill_231: Stands on one foot for 10 seconds or longer.
milestone_60_skill_232: Hops; may be able to skip.
milestone_60_skill_234: Uses a fork and spoon and sometimes a table knife.
milestone_60_skill_235: Can use the toilet on {{hisHersTag}} own.
milestone_6_concern_16: Doesn't try to get things that are in reach.
milestone_6_concern_19: Has difficulty getting things to mouth.
milestone_6_concern_20: Seems very floppy, like a rag doll.
milestone_6_concern_22: Doesn't roll over in either direction.
milestone_6_concern_23: Doesn't laugh or make squealing sounds.
milestone_6_concern_24: Seems very stiff, with tight muscles.
milestone_6_hint_28: Play on the floor with your baby every day.
milestone_6_hint_29: Learn to read your baby's moods. If {{heSheTag}}'s happy, keep doing what you are doing, If {{heSheTag}}'s upset, take a break and comfort your baby.
milestone_6_hint_30: Show your baby how to comfort {{himselfHerselfTag}} when {{heSheTag}}'s upset. {{heSheUpperTag}} may suck on {{himHerTag}} fingers to self soothe.
milestone_6_hint_31: Use "reciprocal play" - when {{heSheTag}} smiles, you smile; when {{heSheTag}} makes sounds, you copy them.
milestone_6_hint_32: Repeat your child's sounds and say simple words with those sounds. For example, if your child says "bah" say "bottle" or "book"
milestone_6_hint_33: Read books to your child every day. Praise {{himHerTag}} when {{heSheTag}} babbles and "reads" too.
milestone_6_hint_34: When your baby looks at something, point to it and talk about it.
milestone_6_hint_35: When {{heSheTag}} drops a toy on the floor, pick it up and give it back. This game helps {{himHerTag}} learn cause and effect.
milestone_6_hint_36: Read colorful picture books to your baby.
milestone_6_hint_37: Point out new things to your baby and name them.
milestone_6_hint_38: Show your baby bright pictures in a magazine and name them.
milestone_6_hint_39: Hold your baby up while {{heSheTag}} sits or support {{himHerTag}} with pillows. Let {{himHerTag}} look around and give {{himHerTag}} toys to look at while {{heSheTag}} balances.
milestone_6_hint_40: Put your baby on {{hisHersTag}} tummy or back and put toys just out of reach. Encourage {{himHerTag}} to roll over to reach the toys.
milestone_6_skill_38: Knows familiar faces and begins to know if someone is a stranger.
milestone_6_skill_39: Likes to play with others, especially parents.
milestone_6_skill_40: Responds to other people's emotions and often seems happy.
milestone_6_skill_41: Likes to look at self in a mirror.
milestone_6_skill_42: Responds to sounds by making sounds.
milestone_6_skill_43: Strings vowels together when babbling ("ah," "eh," "oh") and likes taking turns with parent while making sounds.
milestone_6_skill_45: Makes sounds to show joy and displeasure.
milestone_6_skill_46: Begins to say consonant sounds (jabbering with "m," "b").
milestone_6_skill_49: Shows curiosity about things and tries to get things that are out of reach.
milestone_6_skill_50: Begins to pass things from one hand to the other.
milestone_6_skill_51: Rolls over in both directions (front to back, back to front).
milestone_6_skill_53: When standing, supports weight on legs and might bounce.
milestone_6_skill_54: Rocks back and forth, sometimes crawling backward before moving forward.
milestone_9_concern_26: Doesn't bear weight on legs with support.
milestone_9_concern_29: Doesn't play any games involving back-and-forth play.
milestone_9_concern_31: Doesn't seem to recognize familiar people.
milestone_9_concern_33: Doesn't transfer toys from one hand to the other.
milestone_9_hint_41: Pay attention to the way {{heSheTag}} reacts to new situations and people; try to continue to do things that make your baby happy and comfortable.
milestone_9_hint_42: As {{heSheTag}} moves around more, stay close so {{heSheTag}} knows that you are near.
milestone_9_hint_43: Continue with routines; they are especially important now.
milestone_9_hint_44: Play games with "my turn, your turn"
milestone_9_hint_45: Say what you think your baby is feeling. For example, say, " You are so sad, let's see if we can make you feel better"
milestone_9_hint_46: Copy your baby's sounds and words.
milestone_9_hint_47: Ask for behaviors that you want. For example, instead of saying "don't stand," say "time to sit"
milestone_9_hint_48: Teach cause-and-effect by rolling balls back and forth, pushing toy cars and trucks, and putting blocks in and out of a container.
milestone_9_hint_49: Describe what your baby is looking at. For example, "red, round ball"
milestone_9_hint_50: Talk about what your baby wants when {{heSheTag}} points at something.
milestone_9_hint_52: Read and talk to your baby.
milestone_9_hint_53: Provide lots of room for your baby to move and explore in a safe area.
milestone_9_hint_54: Put your baby close to things that {{heSheTag}} can pull up on safely.
milestone_9_skill_60: May be clingy with familiar adults.
milestone_9_skill_63: Makes a lot of different sounds like "mamamama" and "bababababa"
milestone_9_skill_64: Copies sounds and gestures of others.
milestone_9_skill_65: Uses fingers to point at things.
milestone_9_skill_66: Watches the path of something as it falls.
milestone_9_skill_67: Looks for things {{heSheTag}} sees you hide.
milestone_9_skill_70: Moves things smoothly from one hand to the other.
milestone_9_skill_71: Picks up things like cereal o's between thumb and index finger.
